You would have to have a glucose test carried out to find out.Hyperglycaemia is when there is far too much sugar in the blood stream.  This happens in people with diabetes and they then have to inject some insulin to bring the level down.Hypoglycaemia is when the sugar level in the blood is very low.  You don't have to be a diabetic to suffer from this.   To remedy this problem is to eat or drink something to bring your sugar levels up again.  Although sugary foods will spike the blood sugar up very quickly which OK initially in a hypoglycaemic attack, it is better to eat slow energy release food.Urine and blood tests for diabetes only show up if the level of sugar is above a certain limit.  But you can still have prediabetes symptoms and this can still damage nerves.There is a blood test for diabetes that measures the blood for the average sugar level over a 3 month period.  Can't remember what this test is called at the moment.Best wishes.

question: I am a 35 YO male who has had multiple abdominal hernia surgeries -- three mesh repairs and one nissen fundoplication.  Ever since the surgeries, I'm either reacting to or more sensitive to sugar.Within 2-3 minutes of ingestion of anything containing >2-3 grams of sugar, I receive symptoms of (always) stomach gas and LOUD stomach noises, nausea, abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea (always); itchy face or scalp (usually); headaches and tiredness (occasionally).I've been able to control this all with a very restrictive diet.  Carbs don't seem to be an issue (because they take longer to break down..?), and neither does sugar from fruits.  HFCS is the worst and causes the most immediate problems; cane sugar takes a few more minutes.So here is my question....  With all of the searching I've done, I've not been able to find any justification for my sensitivity, nor have I really heard of anyone else talk about it.  I think this has been a lifelong issue, but the nissen caused me to be more aware, since I can't burp normally.  (I'd always had an aversion to sweet things -- ice cream always caused problems, so did jello.  I always assumed I was lactose and gelatin intolerant..).Because symptoms spring about so immediately (like an allergy) and my symptoms are more than GI-related, I can't imagine it's just an intolerance.  But if anyone else has any advice, I'd greatly appreciate it!
title: Allergic (..Sensitive?) to Sugar?
